text:
With another championship on the line, retired Cubs catcher David Ross finally hit a home run with the "Dancing with the Stars" judges Monday.

Ross and partner Lindsay Arnold earned a perfect 40 out of 40 points for their energetic, Cubs-inspired freestyle routine to a medley of "It Takes Two" and "Take Me Out to the Ball Game" and 33 out of 40 for their Viennese waltz to "Let's Hurt Tonight" by OneRepublic. These scores will help determine who wins Season 24 of the ABC network competition Tuesday.

Advertisement

"Everyone has their own personal best and it looks different obviously, but tonight I definitely feel you hit your personal best. Thank you for giving us the freestyle we wanted," judge Carrie Ann Inaba told Ross and Arnold.

This was the first time the pair earned 10s from the judges. Unfortunately, they didn't fare as well in their first dance of the night, the Viennese waltz, because of Ross' technical flaws.

Advertisement

"David, I've got to say, first, congratulations on making it through to the final. It's a truly Cinderella story. I never dreamt you'd make it to the ball, but here you are," judge Len Goodman said. "There is improvement in your dancing overall, but for me, not so much in the Viennese waltz."

Ross and Arnold are at the bottom of the leaderboard because of the waltz score. NFL running back Rashad Jennings and partner Emma Slater scored 80 out of 80 points Monday, while singer Normani Kordei and pro dancer Valentin Chmerkovskiy earned 78 points.

But the pairs are not done dancing. On Tuesday, each couple will fuse two contrasting dance styles they've performed this season for judges' points. The pairs have less than 24 hours to prepare for that dance.

Viewer votes and judges' points from last week and Monday will be combined with judges' points from the Tuesday 24-hour challenge to determine the winner of the mirror-ball trophy.

Ross acknowledged Monday that he made it to the finals not because of the judges' scores, but via support from his fans and former teammates.

"Just being in the finals, one, is way more than I ever expected and the fact that I've got support from so many great people, and that they look up to me and watch this show and support me, just ... I don't even have the words, just a lot of thanks," Ross said.

Tuesday's two-and-a-half-hour finale is scheduled to begin at 7:30 p.m.
